Potential Impact of the Technology Solution

The SafeHer solution has the potential to transform community safety by leveraging ServiceNow’s automation, workflows, and analytics capabilities to deliver faster, more transparent, and data-driven responses to women’s safety concerns.

1. Faster Emergency Response

Automated workflows connect victims, authorities, and responders in real-time, reducing manual coordination.

Instant alerts to police, family members, and nearby help centers can cut average response time by up to 70%.

Geo-location sharing ensures responders can locate victims quickly and accurately.

2. Increased Reporting and Awareness

Anonymous reporting options and a user-friendly portal encourage women to report incidents safely without fear of exposure.

Data aggregation across cases builds public awareness about high-risk areas and peak times for incidents.

3. Improved Coordination Among Stakeholders

Centralized platform enables seamless collaboration between police departments, NGOs, and emergency responders.

Automated case routing, status updates, and SLAs ensure accountability at every step.

4. Data-Driven Safety Planning

Dashboards and analytics reveal patterns of incidents by time, location, and type, helping authorities deploy resources proactively.

Enables predictive policing and safety measures, such as increasing patrols or improving lighting in risk zones.

5. Enhanced Privacy and Trust

Role-based access and data encryption guarantee complete confidentiality of victim information.

Transparent case tracking builds public confidence in digital safety systems.

6. Empowerment and Community Engagement

Empowers women to take control of their safety through technology.

Promotes community participation — residents, organizations, and authorities can work together on verified data.

Contributes directly to UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDG 5: Gender Equality & SDG 11: Sustainable Cities).

7. Scalable & Replicable Model

Once piloted in one city, the solution can be easily scaled nationwide or adapted for campuses, workplaces, and public spaces.

The platform can integrate with existing helpline systems and expand to include mental health or legal support.

In cities across India and globally, women face daily safety concerns during travel, at workplaces, and even within communities. Existing safety systems are fragmented — emergency numbers, complaint portals, and support services are scattered across different apps and departments, making response times slow and inconsistent.
Many incidents go unreported due to fear, lack of anonymity, or uncertainty about where to seek help.
SafeHer aims to provide a unified, secure, and anonymous platform for women to report safety incidents, request emergency help, access verified support centers, and track the status of their reports — all through ServiceNow.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

Imagine a woman walking home late from work. She feels unsafe and opens the SafeHer mobile app. With just one tap on the SOS button, an alert is automatically sent to the nearest police station, her emergency contacts, and a verified NGO help center — all at once.

The system creates a case in ServiceNow with her live location, time, and type of incident. Authorities can track, respond, and update the case in real time. The woman can also report harassment or unsafe areas anonymously, without sharing her personal details.

Over time, all reported cases are analyzed on a dashboard to identify unsafe zones, helping the police and local bodies take preventive action — like improving street lighting or increasing patrols.

So, the ideal solution is a simple, fast, and connected system that helps women feel safe anywhere, anytime — using technology to bring trust, speed, and visibility into every safety response.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

The SafeHer solution depends on a few key technologies to function smoothly in real-life emergency situations:

  1. ServiceNow Platform – Core foundation for building the app using App Engine, Case Management, and Flow Designer.

  2. Mobile Access – So women can quickly send SOS alerts and track help using their phones through the ServiceNow Mobile App.

  3. Location Tracking – Integration with GPS or Google Maps API to share the user’s exact location with nearby police or help centers.

  4. Communication Channels – SMS, WhatsApp, or email setup to send instant alerts to family members and authorities.

  5. IntegrationHub Connections – To link with external emergency systems like police, hospital, or NGO databases.

  6. Security Controls – Strong access rules and encryption to keep all user data private and protected.

  7. Analytics Dashboard – For authorities to view trends, identify unsafe zones, and plan preventive actions.

 

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Building Trust and Awareness – Many women might hesitate to use a digital platform for safety due to fear or past experiences. It will take strong awareness campaigns and community partnerships to earn trust.

Real-Time Coordination – Handling live alerts means the system must connect instantly with police, hospitals, and NGOs. Any delay or technical glitch could affect emergency response time.

Data Sensitivity – The app will store highly confidential information like locations and personal details. Ensuring encryption, privacy, and secure access control is a top priority.

Connectivity Gaps – In certain rural or low-signal areas, SOS alerts might not send immediately, so offline backup options (like SMS fallback) are important.

Integration Complexity – Each city or region may have different emergency systems, helplines, and contact networks. Integrating them into one smooth workflow will take time and coordination.

Operational Sustainability – After launch, maintaining updated contact databases, 24/7 monitoring, and user support requires long-term funding or partnerships with government agencies.

Scalability – As more users and cities join, the system needs to handle thousands of cases without slowing down or losing accuracy.
